children.value: Practice working through “by hand” examples of diagnosing homophily
Be prepared to computationally diagnose homophily in a large network
Consider your friends. Do they tend to
Enjoy the same movies, music, hobbies as you?
Hold similar religous or political beliefs?
Come from simliar schools, workplaces, or socio-economic settings?
What about a random sample of people in the world?
If you are like me, your answers likely indicate that you have more in common with your friends than you would expect to have with a random sample of people
This concept -- that we are similar to our friends -- is called
In the context of graphs or networks, homophily means that nodes that are connected are
than nodes at a further distance in the graph
But what do we mean by
Idea: We might have common friends.
force that led to node formation (e.g. triadic closure)
Alternative: We may share characteristics or properties that are not represented in the graph --
Examples: same race, gender, school, employer, sports team, etc.
These external forces are what homophily captures
To identify if homophily is active in a network, we must have access to
on top of list of nodes and edges
One way to represent this context would be with a DataFrame in addition to a graph:
One column indicating the node identifier (or just use row number)

using DataFrames, Graphs, GraphPlot

df1 = DataFrame(
    node_id=["Spencer", "Shannen", "Brinley", "MJ", "LeBron"],
    favorite_color=["blue", "pink", "pink", "red", "blue"],
    school=["ucf", "byu", "wes", "unc", "hs"],
    sport=["volleyball", "wakeboarding", "wakeboarding", "basketball", "basketball"],
    favorite_food=["pizza", "burger", "pizza", "burger", "ice cream"],
    gender=['M', 'F', 'F', 'M', 'M'],
)

children.value: Our discussion on homophily so far has been conceptual... let’s make it precise
We’ll frame the discussion in terms of a null hypothesis
Concept should be familiar from statistics, but not exactly the same we we won’t make distributional assumptions
Our analytical approach begins with a thought experiment (counter factual) that all edges are randomly formed
In this case, we should not expect the context around our graph to help us predict its structure

children.html: XXX
NNN
NxN_xNx​
XXX
N−NxN - N_xN−Nx​
px=NxNp_x = \frac{N_x}{N}px​=NNx​​

children.value: The probability that an arbitrary edge is between two nodes that both share

children.html: XXX
px2p_x^2px2​

children.value: Probability of edge between two non

children.html: XXX
(1−px)2(1-p_x)^2(1−px​)2
XXX
XXX

prob(edge (X <=> not X))=px(1−px)+(1−px)px=2px(1−px)\begin{aligned}\text{prob}(\text{edge (X <=> not X)}) &= p_x (1-p_x) + (1-p_x) p_x \\ &= 2 p_x (1-p_x)\end{aligned}prob(edge (X <=> not X))​=px​(1−px​)+(1−px​)px​=2px​(1−px​)​

children.value: This will be our “random edge formation” benchmark

exxe_{xx}exx​

eyye_{yy}eyy​
XXX
exye_{xy}exy​

e=exx+eyy+exye = e_{xx} + e_{yy} + e_{xy}e=exx​+eyy​+exy​

children.value: We are now ready to test for homophily
We’ll consider the assumption (null hypothesis) that there is no homophily in characteristic

children.html: XXX
⟹\Longrightarrow⟹

children.value: observed proportion of cross-characteristic edges is (approximately) the same as characteristic frequencies in the full population
To test this assumption, we compare

children.html: 2px(1−px)2 p_x(1-p_x)2px​(1−px​)

children.value: : the likelihood of a cross-characteristic edge forming, under the assumption of purely random edge formation

children.html: exye\frac{e_{xy}}{e}eexy​​

children.value: : the proportion of cross-characteristic edges that exist in the network
When comparing these statistics, we could get one of three outcomes:

children.html: exye>>2px(1−px)\frac{e_{xy}}{e} >> 2 p_x(1-p_x)eexy​​>>2px​(1−px​)
exye≈2px(1−px)\frac{e_{xy}}{e} \approx 2 p_x(1-p_x)eexy​​≈2px​(1−px​)
exye<<2px(1−px)\frac{e_{xy}}{e} << 2 p_x(1-p_x)eexy​​<<2px​(1−px​)

children.value: Intuition: If observed cross characteristic edge formation is significantly less than what we’d expected under random edge formation, we reject the hypothesis that homophily is not present, and conclude that characteristic

children.html: XXX

children.value: Recall the graph of romantic relationships between high school students
: does this graph exhibit homophily in gender? Why?
Let’s work through an example of numerically dianosing homophily using our made up data

5LeBronbluehsbasketballice creamM

children.value: First we need to count frequencies for all our characteristics

data.name: stderr
data.text:
[32m[1m   Resolving[22m[39m package versions...
[32m[1m  No Changes[22m[39m to `~/.julia/environments/v1.10/Project.toml`
[32m[1m  No Changes[22m[39m to `~/.julia/environments/v1.10/Manifest.toml`

children.value:
function count_frequencies(vals)
    counts = DataStructures.counter(vals)
    total = length(vals)
    Dict(c => v / total for (c, v) in pairs(counts))
end

Dict(
    n => count_frequencies(df1[!, n])
    for n in names(df1)[2:end]

)

text/plain.content:

  "favorite_color" => Dict("blue"=>0.4, "pink"=>0.4, "red"=>0.2)
  "gender"         => Dict('M'=>0.6, 'F'=>0.4)
  "school"         => Dict("wes"=>0.2, "byu"=>0.2, "unc"=>0.2, "ucf"=>0.2, "hs"…
  "favorite_food"  => Dict("burger"=>0.4, "ice cream"=>0.2, "pizza"=>0.4)
  "sport"          => Dict("volleyball"=>0.2, "wakeboarding"=>0.4, "basketball"…

children.value: Next we need to count the number of edges of each type
This step is a bit tricker as it will require that we access both data from the Graph and the DataFrame
To not spoil the fun, we’ll leave this code as an exercise on the homework
For now we’ll look at things “by hand”
and test if edges form based on favorite color being blue

children.html: (exy)(e_{xy})(exy​)

children.value: The ratio of cross edges is 5/6
The ratio of nodes that like blue is 2/5 (

children.html: pxp_xpx​

children.value:
E = ne(g1)
Exy = 5
n_blue = 2
N = nv(g1)
px = n_blue / N

# test
2 * px * (1-px), Exy/E
cross edges formed than we would expect
Repeat the counting exercise, but for the gender and favorite sport characteristics
What do you find? Do either of these characteristcs exhibit homophily?
